div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

MONDAY, JULY 8, 1907.

div.head: THE LORDS DEBATE
div.p: Here are some of the comments of the Press on the resolution against the Lords.

"The Government plan is simple, and certainly if it errs at all," says the "Daily News," does not err on the side of too drastic treatment of the hereditary chamber. Anything less would mean the frank acceptance of the subordination of the elected House; a uni-cameral system when the Tories are in power; Liberalism and progress in a condition of permanent enslavement and impotence." Every argument which the Opposition put forward in favour of a Second Chamber "is an argument against the House of Lords" "It is an obviously effective, though undoubtedly a rather cumbrous, plan, and a good many people will be inclined to think with Mr. Shackleton that one of the offers to the Lords might be lopped from it," says the 'Tribune," which also declares that the scheme "represents the irreducible minimum of reform." "The proposal is one of great moderation, while yet, within the limits," says the "Daily Chronicle," "of real efficacy. To attempt anything less would be to acquiesce in pretensions fatal alike to the rights and liberties of the Commons, and to the possibility of serious Liberal reform." In the opinion of the "Morning Leader," which declares that "Democracy has come to grips with privilege," the plan "is in a very high degree satisfactory." "If," says the "Westminster Gazette," "the Tory Party are really sincere in acknowledging that the will of the country must prevail, they have here a scheme which effects the object without disturbing the constitution of the House of Lords."

Feeling sure after reading his speech that Mr. Balfour must have "had his tongue in his cheek," and regretting the Premier's attitude against the Referendum, the "Manchester Guardian" says: —"It is not sufficient to pronounce the Government's scheme bad; it is necessary to find a better." The "Guardian" notes with approval Lord Robert Cecil's admission that "the existing system operates one-sidedly." The surprising feature of the debate, says the "Liverpool Post," is "the absence of any substantial arguments against the proposals of the Prime Minister." The Opposition, declare* the 'Sooth Wales Daily News," "have a miserable oase to defend, and Mr. Balfour defended it miserably." "The date of the next General Election," says the "Leeds Mercury," "may be accurately forecasted when the date for the introduction of the Lords' Veto Bill is known."

"Seldom, if ever," declares the 'Times," has a change of such moment been urged in a speech displaying so little sense of responsibility, or based upon such flimsy grounds" Sir Henry seems to be returning to the obsolete theory that the House of Commons—meaning in practice any chance majority of the House of Commons—is the true Sovereign, and not the nation. The only reason which the Prime Minister could assign for his proposal was the party complexion of the House of Lords, which makes it passive under a Unionist Government, and active only when the Liberals are in power. Now, even if we assume this contention to be true, it is worth noting, as Liberals have noted, that the Government plan is a very imperfect remedy."

"The devil can quote Scripture when it suits his ends, and Sir Henry Campbell- Bannerman, excellent man, will talk Constitutionalism when he wishes to bring about Revolution," says the "Standard" "Two courses are open: either to strengthen the House of Lords by restoring its character as an assembly selected on grounds of special competence for the work to be done or to weaken it by diminishing its powers. Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman has chosen the second and as it seems to us, the less judicious and less promising course," says the "Morning Post" "To the crude formula that, the Commons shall prevail," says the "Daily Telegraph" "the unanswerable Unionist retort is that the country shall prevail, and that the Peers shall prevail with it whenever they are shown to be, as in 1893 and now, the true interpreters of national opinion."

"Mr. Morley, reflecting on Mr Gladstone's Parliamentary vicissitudes, quoted with appreciation the saying by Sorel that politics are a game of chance They would become a game of great national peril," says the "Scotsman," if the counsels of the present Prime Minister were accepted"

div.p: The construction of the prison at Daman- hour has been adjudicated to the Egyptian I'onsiraetion Company, Ltd. at an estimate of L.E.16,052.

div.head: Sakkia Fatality
div.p: While a sakkia was being worked on Satur- day the earth immediately surrounding it gave way, and the man in charge of the Sakkia fell into the well and was drowned.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: The latest plague bulletins report 1 case at Beni-Souef, 3 recoveries at Beni-Mazar, 1 death at Damanhour, and 1 case and death at Esneh. Fourteen cases remain under treatment.

div.head: Inter-Regimental Polo
div.p: Our sports correspondent telegraphs from Cairo:— In the inter regimental polo tour- nament of England, the 20th Hussars won by 6 goals to 4 against the 11th Hussars.

div.head: The Atbara Flood
div.p: The Acting Governor of Berber Province notifies that the Atbara flood has come down and that all travellers and stores proceeding to Kassala should henceforth proceed via Berber or Atbora.

div.head: San Stefano Casino
div.p: The San Stefano Casino offers subscriptions for entry for the season. The personal ticket is P.T. 20O and the family ticket P.T. 350. Applications should be addressed to the secre- tary of the Casino.

div.head: The Cartibaldi Centenary
div.p: The Garibaldi centenary whs celebrated in Alexandria yesterday with great fervour. Last night San Stefano Casino was crowded, and dancing was continued until after midnight. The Consular Corps was well represented, and among other local celebrities were the Sub- Governor ami M. Escoffier.

div.head: Fires In Cairo
div.p: A fire broke out on Thursday morning in the house of Ibrahim Bey Abd el Messieh at Fagallah and was extinguished by the fire brigade after two hours' work. The damages have not yet been estimated, but the value of the house was L.E. 5,000. In the evening of the same day at about 10 o'clock another fire broke out in Restaurant Bella Venezia, Sharieh el Mahdy, belonging to Tobia Diano,an Italian. The damages are extensive but have not yet been estimated.

div.head: Cairo Police News.
div.p: At Darb-el-Ahmar, a young girl named Zakieh Bint Madi Saleh died from the sting of a scorpion. On Friday morning at 11, Zaki Gabriel, from Tahta, fell when getting off the tram in Sharieh Shoubra and has been so badly injured that little hope is left of recovery. This morning, a Council of Discipline will meet at the Governorate to hear the case of Mulazin Awal Izzet Eff. Shaoukat, maowin Quaily Caracol, for fill-treatment of a prisoner. He had already been transferred in disgrace to Old Cairo caracol.

div.head: The Indian Mail
div.p: Both press and public in India are indig- nant at the terms of the recent contract for the mail service between the United Kingdom and India. It is declared that the slight acceleration of eight hours only rep- resents a possible quickening of the Suez Canal transit, and implies no increased speed in the ocean voyage. Objection is taken to the length of the contract, as no progres- sive diminution of the voyage is insisted on. It is felt that whatever the improve- ments in marine propulsion in the future no benefit will accrue to the Indian Service.

div.head: TRIESTE HARBOUR WORKS
div.p: The clone connection between Alexandria and Trieste renders the question of the impro- vement of the harbour at the Austrian port of considerable interest His Majesty's Embassy at Vienna has forwarded a memorandum of the proposed new harbour works at Trieste, from which the following is taken : The inadequate nature of the harbour works at Trieste has always formed an obstacle in the way of the free development of the Austro- Hungarian export trade, the steady increase in which has recently drawn special attention to the insufficiencies of the principal port of the Dual Monarchy. It is universally admitted in commercial circles that the requirements of an ever-growing traffic towards the sonth must be met by a corresponding enlargement and improvement of the port of Trieste. This question has recently been taken up actively by the Government,and the Austrian Minister of Commerce,Dr. Forscht, accompanied by a number of experts, has visited Trieste with the ob- ject of studying the subject, and of conferring with the municipal and maritime authorities as to the nature and extent of the improvements to be undertaken. The discussion of the new projects is beset with considerable difficultes owing to the fact of many conflicting com- mercial interests being at stake, but the matter is one which will not be allowed to drop, and it may be confidently anticipated that a de- finite derision will be arrived at before long as to the nature and scope of the improvements. In the meanwhile new harbomr works are already in course of construction and are being pushed on as rapidly as possibly.

div.head:
LORD CROMER'S GRANT
THE RADICAL ATTITUDE
div.p: We understand that when the resolution for a special grant of £50,000 to Lord Cromer is proposed by the Prime Minister, the Radical group of members of Parliament, who take a special interest in Egyptian affairs, will support the vote, although as Radicals they are opposed in principle to all grants and pensions. This attitude sounds somewhat illogical, but they feel that Lord Cromer's work in Egypt, taken as a whole and apart from certain shortcomings due to idiosyncrasy, is deserving of exceptional recognition and that his salary was insufficient, having regard to the calls made upon him, for him to have put by any money for the peerage and the younger sons. These Radicals also consider that Lord Cromer is much more entitled to £50,000 than Lord Roberts was to double that sum for the war that he did not finish, and that the amount proposed in Lord Cromer's case is by no means exorbitant. Mr. W Redmond and the Irish Parliamentary Party are going to oppose the grant.

div.head:
LORD CROMER MEMORIAL
TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
div.p: Dear Sir, Upon the 17th June you kindly accorded me space for the insertion of copy of my circular letter addressed to the British resi- dents. I wish, before leaving Alexandria, to state the results. Over one thousand circulars were issued by post or by hand, addressed in accordance with the latest completed list obtainable from the British Consulate. 130 of these have hern returned throngh the dead letter office, and 29 replies have been received. Until more public interest has been taken in the matter it appears to me to be useless to publish any details. However. I take this opportunity of thanking those of my fellow subjects who have sup- ported me. I am, Yours faithfully. Robert J Mow. Alexandria, 8th July 1907.

div.head: THE STATE RAILWAYS.
div.p: The railway administration have requested their superior council to grant the following credits. 1. L.E 5,000 for the improvement of stations, enlargement of signal boxes etc. These alterations have been made necessary in certain stations by the extension of the traffic. 2. L.E 45,000 for the purchase of locomo- tives, wagons and material for the narrow gauge line between Keneh and Assouan. These additions will be necessary for the transporting of material for the raising of the Assouan dam. 3. LE 6,500 for the enlargement of Shibin-el Kanater station.

div.head:
THE DIAMOND SKULLS.
CAIRO OFFICER WINS.
div.p: We are glad to be able to report that Capt Darrell of the Coldstream Guards, now sta- tioned at Cairo, has won the Diamond Skulls:

Capt. Darrell was the runner up last year, and had bad luck in not winning. We offer him our sincere congratulations on his success this year. "An Old Blue" writing in the "Daily Telegraph" previous to the race said:-

"Blackstaffe does not seem to me to be as fast as last year, and if I am right he will need all the advantage of the station on Tuesday to get the better of Clotte, who is much improved and better of boated. Darrell and McCulloch should get through the first round, but if Powell appears in his first heat, the Oxford man will get no further. Both McCulloch and Edye are men who will do well in this race later on, but their first attempt is more likely to give them valuable experience than unexpected victory. Darrell should get into the final, for he knows more of the game, and is as fit and resolute as ever. Powell is not likely to get tired in the Goblets, for if previous form goes for anything, nothing but an accident can prevent him and Johnstone winning; unluckily the weat her does not seem likely to facilitate their making the record they could easily have got last year had they known their time at Fawley."

div.head: EGYPTIAN NATIONALISTS AND CONGO FREE STATE.
div.p: The following comments on the "Egyptian Standard" appear in the "Times" above the signature of "Delta"

"English Radicals who are inclined to take Mustapha Pasha Kamel and his "Nationalist" followers at their own valuation may be inter- ested to learn that, whilst British control in Egypt is sheer oppression and men like Lord Cromer intolerable despots, the Congo Free State and its Sovereign are objects of deserving sympathy in the eyes of Egyptian patriots. The "Egyptian Standard " of June 18 quotes with great complacency the whitewashing report lately issued by the Congo authorities and especially its glorification of King Leopold. For the report, it seems, refutes "the attacks upon the Sovereign of the Congo State," which according to Mustapha Pasha's organ, "have proceeded from the Imperialist Press in England, whose appetite is ferocious and insa- tiable."

div.head:
EGYPTIAN ARCHAEOLOGY
BRITISH SCHOOL'S EXHIBITION
div.p: The annual visits to Egypt of Professor Flinders Petrie and his faithful assistants of the British School of Archaeology in Egypt are invariably productive of valuable results, and, thanks to their untiring labours, our knowledge of anoieet Egypt civilization is being continually enlarged, and with it our interest in this wonderful country and its people. The British school deserve all the assistance it is possible to give them.

Last winter the work of the school was devoted to excavations at Ghizeh and Ritah, and the exhibition of the antiquities found at these places, which was opened at University College yesterday, is one of the meet interest- ing and instructive yet seen. From these exhibits we learn that Egypt had a unified civilisation more than 8,000 years before the Christian era. This civilisation is found to have been exactly the same soon after the founding of Memphis as it was in a given reign at Abydos, and the unification of the country is shown by the absence of local differences. A very interesting discovery at Ghizeh was a tomb of the first dynasty, dated to the reign of King Zet. The central chambers had been cleared of their contents for the Cairo Museum, but the surroundings were excavated and plans made by the British School The tomb was probably that of some royal personage, for around it were found over fifty small graves, about half of which contained remains, which, however, had been plundered in ancient times. A number of alabaster vases and bowls of metamorphic rock and slate were found in these graves, which are of exactly the style of the contemporary vases from the royal tombs at Abydos, and show that there was no differ- ence of style between the upper and lower country. In the royal tomb the central burial was in a wooden chamber, and the offerings were in four chambers, two at each end of the great burial. Over this was a brick mastaba with panelled sides, similar to that over Mena's grave at Nagada.

Undoubtedly the most valuable of all the discoveries were the pottery models of the soul houses, found near Assiout The cemetery was of the tenth-eleventh dynasties, and was excavated from under a bed of gravel. The accumulation from the hills had gradually buried those pottery models of houses which were placed upon the graves for the shelter of the soul. In the earliest times offerings were made in the cemetery to satisfy the wandering soul when it came out of the tomb at night to search for sustenance. A mat was placed upon the ground, and a dish of flour set upon it.

From this series we are able to obtain a very good idea of the houses of the peasantry of this period. The earliest type of house had a rooflike a Bedawy tent propped up with two poles in front, which passed on into the form of a portico, later the portico had a raised wall around the roof, which in turn required a stairway to reach it. Then a hut was placed beneath the portico, which developed into a back chamber with doorways. In some of these houses we see models of artistic furniture, a couch with a head-rest upon it, a chair, while a bread-maker is often shown at work.

Another striking feature of the exhibition is a splendid tomb of the twelfth dynasty, in which two sons of the Prince of Shas-Hotep were buried. The tomb is in perfect condition, and is one of the finest known of this period. The inner case is elaborately painted, and the hieroglyphs are minutely drawn, showing de- tails of the animals. The inscription is a fol- lows -. "Give an offering to the King and to = Osiris lord of Daddu the great god lord of Abydos, may he give a house of offerings, oxen, geese, clothing, and incense for the kq of the devoted son of the prinoe Nekht-Ankh born of Khnumu-A.A.". From this tomb were taken two excellent models of boats, one with the mast removed, and the sail packed upon it, as if being rowed down the Nile, the other with the mast up, and the crew engaged in hauling up the yard. Each boat has a cabin, in front of which the captain is seated. The steering oars are perfect, and finely painted with eyes of Horus, lotus flowers, and rosettes on the blade. Bach has a long guiding pole attached to it, and the steersman holds this with one hand so as to rotate the great oar for steering, as on the boats seen on Lake Como at the present day.

There are many more points of interest, not the least striking of which are the beautiful alabaster and breccia vases, curious ivory magic wands, carved ivories, and the beautiful head work. The exhibition will be open until July 27.

div.head: NEXT SEASON's PLANS
div.p: During next season the British school hopes to commence the excavation of Memphis, and an appeal to the public for funds has already been issued. Professor Petrie says that the annual cost of this work, which he expects will occupy 15 or 20 years, will be about £8,000, and in view of the value which will attach to the discoveries at this ancient site, it is hoped that the appeal for funds will be generously responded to. The site occupies about one hundred acres, and it is expected operations will commence as soon as the Nile is down, probably about the beginning of January next. Professor Petrie will again have the assistance of Mr. Ernest Mackay, and, during a part of each season, of Mr. Howard Carter, who will undertake the artistic work, besides a number of student helpers. The expe- dition will leave England in November.

div.head:
AN EX-OFFICER'S PLIGHT.
HIS WORK AT SUAKIN.
div.p: The following statement appears in the "Standard."

An instance of neglect and hardship towards a humble builder of Empire in a far outpost has come to our notice, and we gladly bring the matter before our readers in the hope that some better fortune may come to the victim through the publication of the particulars of his case.

Mr. J.F. Mason will be remembered by all those who visited Suakin between 1887 and 1900 as the "Officer Commanding Condensers." The lack of water in that disagreeable outpost of Empire had to be met, as is well known, by the erection of plant to condense sea water into fresh.

For some time this was done at a great expense, until Mr. Mason conceived the idea of finding water in the desert outside the town. Starting on the theory that where the coral reef is broken, tlie breech is due to the fact of an outflow of fresh water which prevents the coral from growing. Mr. Mason set to work, and found a splendid supply in a khor at Fort Charter. This in itself is an achievement well worthy of reward.

For 13 years Mr. Mason worked hard at Suakin, and in the troublous times during Lord Kitchener's ad ranee, Mr. Mason formed friendships with the Hadendowa tribe, and alone of all the white man in the fortress went freely among them.

Owing to the economies which were found necessary by the Egyptian Government, Mr. Mason's appointment became superfluous, and in consequence, he left the Egyptian service, without a pension, as he did not come under the terms of the Khedive's pension list

We regret to say that Mr. Mason is now re- duced to want and is looking for an appoint- ment as an engineer. He would admirably fill the position of an engineer and carpenter to an estate, or some similar work. We have inquired into his case, and feel that it is one that we ran heartily recommend. Lord Kitchen- er, writing under date March 6, gives the following testimony:-

"Mr. F. Mason worked under me for many years in Egypt where he was in charge of the condensers at Suakin. I know him to be a good, hard working, reliable man, and I am very sorry to hear that he is now out of employment."

We hope that some employer of labour will be able to find a place for a very deserving man, who has given the best part of his life to arduous labour in a most insalubrious climate. Inquires will be gladly answered by the Editor.

div.head: THEATRICAL PERFORMANCE AT ABBASSIA.
div.p: A second performance of "In Barcelona," by Mr. G.A. Campbell, was given at Abbassia Barracks on Saturday evening last before an appreciative audience of soldiers and civilians together with their families. "In Barcelona" is a musical-comedy of stereotyped composition, wound round an essentially meediocre plot, but, at the same time, containing many humorous local references and much pithy wit. Judging the production from a friendly, rather than a critical, aspect the author is to be congratulated upon his artistic ability and upon the many excellent theatrical touches, which he has so successfully introduced into the play. From a musical point of view the comedy was a marked success, the rendering of some of the songs being faultless and the choruses were also most effective. It is obvious that Messrs. Keppel and Lawrence, who were respon- sible for several of the best additional num- bers and lyrics, have a good knowledge of their subject. Mr. Campbell proved himself an indefatigable singer of the first order, an Pte. A. Horrocks, as a Spanish brigand, gave a very true conception of his part.

The play itself lost nothing by the acting, which was distinctly talented and above the usual standard of amateur theatrical per- formances of this kind, although at times their was an unfortunate tendency to lower the voice, so much so indeed, that, in the case of Mr. Orred, as Mabel Brown, nothing what- ever could be heard, even in the front rows. Drummer A. Hawes, as a waiter, was extremely funny, but he occasionally sacrificed the humour of the situation for the sake of exaggerated acrobatic contortions. The Hon. Keppel, as Herr von Rodel, who performed his part very cleverly, deserves special mention, if only on account of his skilful sustainment of a difficult foreign accent. Sergt. Silver, as a chauffeur, was perhaps the most successful actor of the company; his elocution was excep tionally sound and he entered into the spirit of his part with an enthusiasm and discretion, quite remarkable.

In short, the entire performance was of a high standard and justly merited the storm of applause with which each item was received. The scenery was excellent the costumes were artistic, and the orchestra, conducted by Drum-Major Richardson, contributed in no small degree to the success of the piece. In fact nothing marred the enjoyment of the evening, unless, perhaps, the somewhat pro- longed interval between the acts, which delay was responsible for those present missing the last tram, and one heartily sympathised with the little child behind, who fretfully asked "When are they going to pull up the blind?"

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman liner Assiout arrived at Liverpool on Saturday morning last.

div.head:
THE LOST CAMEL CORPS.
STATEMENT BY SIR E GREY.
div.p: Mr. Kettle having asked the Foreign Secre- tary whether he is now in a position to give information as to certain casualtiesreported to have bean sustained by No. 2 Company, Camel Corps, which left for Bir Natron, under Bim- bashi Whittingham, in Frebruary last, Sir Edward Grey said: -The garrison of Bir Natron evacuated that post on April 10 or 15, intending to pro used to Abe Tbberi. where they expected to meet the convoy of supplies which had left Debba on March 12. The party consisted of one officer, 40 men, eight women, one child, 38 camels, and a guide. On the fourth day of their march, having failed to reach Abu Tabari, the guide confessed that he had lost his way, and advised that scouts should be sent out. Two parties were accordingly despatched, of which one found the convoy above referred to, from which they obtained water for their party, and retraced their steps On regaining their party they found only 11 men,seven women, and a boy; the officer, 19 men, one woman, and two Arabs having for some reason which cannot he ascertained, gone southwards with all the camels. A search party was sent out to find them, but a dust storm frustrated their efforts, and the remainder of party, with the help of the convoy, moved into Abu Tabari. From there information as to the incident was sent to Khandak, and search parties were at once sent out, with the result that the second aooating party were discovered alive; but although every effort was made no trace could be found of the officer's party which had started south, wife the exception of one body. It is, therefore, to be feared that the officer, Mulazim Awal Ali Effendi Hassan, and the 22 persons with him have lost their lives. All the survivors are well and have arrived at El Bab, in Wadi el Kab

div.head: THE COTTON MARKET
div.p: Writing from Liverpool under date of the 29th ult. Messrs. Codings Brothers report the manipulation still continuing in the near positions both in Liverpool and in New York keeps the market in a nervous state. Mean- while, as far as the new crop is concerned, we have had another week of generally favorable news and the coming Agricultural Bu- reau's Report on the "condition" will doubtless shew a considerable improvement. At present the general idea seems to be about 6 to 7 improvement on the month.

div.head:
BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
(Aujourd'hui a midi).
div.p: Comme dans les seances precedentes, les affaires ont ete insignifiantes et limitees a quelques titres. Le tout n'aurait pas exige plus d'un quart d'heure pour etre conclu. Nous ne voyons pas dans ces conditions pourquoi I'ho raire a ete porte de 1 heure a 1 heure et demie. Quant aux fluctuations elles nont, bien entendu, ssans importance et representent plutot des cours nominaux.

La Cassa di Sconto donne toujours lieu a des pourparlers mais sans affaires effectives. Les pretentions des vendeurs teudent paralt il, a dimineur, puisque le prix s'inscrit a 45 francs, en baisse de 3 francs sur celui de vendredi dernier.

Les valeurs diregeantes profitent de la plus- value gagnee a Londres, sans toutefois attein- dre iei le meme niveau: L'Agricole se main- tient a 7 13/16 acheteurs; la National Bank s'avance de 19 5/8 19 13/16, la Delta Light de 9 a 9 1/8, I'Obligation Credit Foncier de 312 Fancienne at 264 1/2 la nouvelle a 314 et 265 respectivement.

Coomme le Credit Foncier, les Lots Turcs be neficient d'une plus-value notable. Leur cours progresse de 158 a 162; ce qui semble prouver que l'epargne cherche des placements plus stables que les valeurs nouvelles cependant offertes au rabais.

En hausse encore I'Alexandrria Water de 10 1/4 a 10 1/2, la Salt & Soda de 17/9 a 18, la Banque d'Athenes de 115 a 155 1/2, les Esta- tes de 21/32 a 11/16, I'Urbaine de 3 3/4 a 3 13/16, I'Union Fonciere de 4 3/4 a 4 13/16.

La Ramleh fleebit, au contraire, de 4 7/8 a 4 13/16, les jouissances Eaux du Caire de 184 a 180, les Markets de 25 a 24/6, la Delta Land de 1 11/16 a 1 5/8, I'Ordinary Khedivial Mail de 22/6, a 21/6, le Comptoir de 3 a 2 3/4 l'action ancienne et de 2 7/8 a 2 5/8 la nouvelle, la Building Lands de 2 7/16 a 2 5/16, le Banco di Roma de 106 a 105 1/2, le Credit Franco-Egyptien de 4 1/16 a 4, la Ban- que d'Orient de 115 1/2 a 115, l'Helouan de 7/16 a 3/8, la Zriffa de 3 1/2 a 3 3/8 l'action et de 8 a 7 la fondateur.
En United, qui a donne lieu a un nombre assez considerable de transactions, l'action ent un peu plus faible a 3/8, tandis que la patt de fondateur beneficie de 1/4 de livre a 2 1/4.

On a beaucoup resarque que l'Alexandria Water, qui etait en baisse continue depuis la mise a l'ordre du jour de la Commission Mu- nicipale de l'interpellation Fenderl an sujet de la nouvelle emission d'actions de cette so- ciete, reprend graduellemont depuis que la Commission, dans sa dernitre seance, a vote quiil n'y avait pas lieu de s'arreter aux obser- vations de M. Fenderl.

Il est question de nouveaux arrangements proposes par le Conseil d'Administration de la Bourse and Banking (Arditi). Comme cepen- dant les assertions sont contradictoires a ce sujet, nous attendrons de'etre exactement fixes sur la version officielle. Le comite des courtiers en valeurs s'occupe activement de cette mal heureuse affaire.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Sir Eldon and Lady Gorst will occupy Shielbridge Lodge during part of the shooting season, when Mr. Rudd will be at Glenborrodale House. Mr. C. D. Rudd is staying at Shielbridge Lodge, one of his places in the north of Argyllshire, for a few weeks salmon fishing.

Mr. and Mrs. R. J. Moss and Miss Moss left Alexandria this morning for Port Said, to embark on board the P. and O.S.S. "Britannia" for Marseilles. Mr. and Mrs. Moss will spend four months in England, and expect to be back early in November.

It is with very great regret that we record the death of Madame Helene Schiess Pasha nee Trieon, who passed away on Saturday evening. The funeral took place yesterday at 1:30p.m. the body being juterred at the Catholic cemetary, and was attended by many of Schiess Pasha's inumerable friends. We beg to offer Schiess Pasha our most sincere condolences in his sad affliction.
Lewa Mansfield Pasha, Commandant of the Cairo City Police, has obtained an ordinary leave of 2 months and 25 days to begin from the 20th instant.
Mr. J.M. Johnson, Sub-Inspector to the Ministry of the Interior, and Abdel Ghami Saker Bey, the Mudir of Kalioubieh have obtained a leave of 2 months and 25 days each.
Mr. George Walker, of Walker and Meima mehi's Ltd., has left for Europe, and during his absence he will be replaced by Mr. C. Sendar Hochatrasser, who has just returned from leave.
The marriage arranged between M. Eric S. Stephenson, D.S.O., Gloucestershire Regiment, attached to the Egyptian Army, and Miss Sibyl Ashmead Bartlett will not take place.

Among those who left for Europe by the Austrian Lloyd mail boat were, Sir Eldon Gorst, Mrs. Brachs Pasha, Mr. M. Cattaul, Mr. and Miss Haicalis, M.G.J. Cernish, Mr. S. Gallichi, Mrs. T. Haas, Baren E. de Hein, Baron E. de Masce, Mr. and Mrs. Padea Bey, Mrs. and Misses Von Pitner, Mrs. N. Sinadino, Mr. R. Stross, Mr. D.E. Smith, Mr. Vaughan Williams, and Mr. F. Clarke.

The following visitors are staying at the Beau-Rivage Hotel, Ramleh:-Mr. and Mrs. A. Berthy and family, Mr. L Limpritis, Mr. and Mrs. H, Giglie, Mr. and Mrs. Miller and family, Mr. and Mrs. M. Mascraft and family Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Phipps, Mr. and Mrs. C. Beale, Mr. and Mrs. A. Hawke, Mr. and Mrs. E.B. Franklin, Mr. E. Turianelli, Miss Humphrey, Miss Cuttes, Mr. Ch. Goodman, Mr. O. Gill, Mrs. R. Lindley Maitland and family, Mr. James Watson, Mr. and MRs. R. Perroth, Mr. O. Muller.

div.head: A.C.C. v. VICTORIA COLLEGE
div.p: Victoria College easily defeated au XI of the A.C.C. on Saturday last. Aubrey and Lias hatted steadily and then V. R. Mustard, taking advantage of the fielding, which really can only be described as disgraceful hit the bowling about freely. After he left E. Harle was the only one to give any trouble to the bowlers, and stood up very pluckily to Carver's fast balls. Hay was the only one on the Club side to make runs, Mustard bowling very well and taking 7 wickets for 31 runs:
VICTORIA COLLEGE

div.head:
THE HAGUE CONFERENCE.
VIOLATION OF PRIVATE PROPERTY.
PROHIBITION OF DRIFTING MINES.

div.p: Sir E. Satow, on behalf of Great Britain, rejected the American proposal with regard to the inviolability of private property at sea on the ground that it tended to limit the right to blockade. What Great Britain thought neces- sary was to establish respect of the right of neutrals, hence her proposal regarding the abolition of contraband. Germany is apparently the only Power opposing the prohibition of drifting mines. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE AMERICAN FLEET.
ITS AUTUMN TOUR.

div.p: The fleet will probably sail early in the autumn. The voyage will occupy 60 days. It is believed that after reaching Peru it will pro- ceed more deliberately than before, apparently because it could in case of emergency then reach San Francisco before any other fleet. Three additional battleships and several cruisers will join the fleet in the Pacific. (Reuter)

div.head:
SERIOUS CARRIAGE ACCIDENT
SIR A. J. HERBERT INJURED.

div.p: Sir A. J. Herbert, British Minister in Nor- way, was driving between Bergen and here when his horses shied at a passing cyclist. The carriage was precipitated down a steep incline and Sir A. Herbert was severely injured. He has had three ribs broken. His condition is not dangerous. Lady Herbert escaped unhurt. (R.)
An unsuccessful attempt was made on Saturday to blow up the reactionary Governor of Anhui whilst he was reviewing cadets. Three persons were killed and one injured (Reuter)

div.head:
THE WINE CRISIS.
CONTINUATION OF STRIKE.

div.p: The mayors of the arrondissement have decided to continue the administrative strike. (Havas)
The Municipal Council has decided to reassert its resignation on the 16th August. (II)
The Cabinet has accepted the German Bank proposals and referred them to a secret parliamentary committee. (Reuter)
Salar-ed-Dowleh has proceeded here under an escort. (Reuter)
M. Clemenceau denies the rumour that he had an interview with M. Tittoni. (Havas)

div.head:
STANDARD OIL COMPANY
ROCKEFELLER SUBPOENAED.
40% DIVIDEND.

div.p: Mr. Rockefeller, who was subpoenaed by a clever ruse to give information regarding the Standard Oil Company's operations ap- peared in court here. The judge failed to elicit much information, Mr. Rockefeller de- claring that he had not participated actively in the Company's affairs for many years. He admitted that the dividend paid in 1906 amounted to about 40%. (Reuter)

Chamber of Deputies. Speaking with regard to Morocco, M. Pichon referred with gratifica- tion to the good relations prevailing after the temporary difficulties between the French and German Legations. He reiterated the essential- ly conservative and pacific character of the Spanish agreements. (Reuter)
The imports for June show a decrease of £71,005 and the exports an increase of £2,471,882 over the same period last year. (Reuter)
The Chamber has passed the bill completing the one against wine adulteration. (Havas)
The gas staff has gone on strike. (Havas)
A slight fire broke out during the night aboard the cruiser "Hoche." (Havas)
Six new arrests arising from the arrest of M. Ferroul have been made. (Havas)
At the four senatorial elections held to-day, three Radicals and one Socialist Radical were elected. (Havas)
A man out of work, who wanted to have himself arrested, tore down "Le Deluge" pic- ture of Poussin, which was at the Louvre. (II)
A cruiser has been despatched to Rotter- dam in consequence of the serious situation brought about by a strike of dock labourers. A large force of marines is assisting the police. (Reuter)
Cambridge beat Oxford by 5 wickets. South Africans beat Sussex by 40 runs.
The match between Gloucestershire and Somerset has been drawn.
The following matches have been abandon- ed: Yorkshire v. Notts and Lancashire v. Northamptonshire.
Warwickshire beat Leicestershire by 8 wickets at Coventry. (Reuter)
M. Fallieres has entertained at dinner the members of the Persian Mission who came to announce the accession of the Shah (Reuter)
Dock labourers have gone on strike here, demanding increase of pay. (Reuter)

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
"BACCHANTE" AT PORT SAID.
div.p: During the visit of H.M.S. "Bacchante" to Port Said an "At Home" was given on the International Sports Club ground at Port Said by Mr. D.A. Cameron, H.B.M.'s Consul-General to Rear Admiral Sir H. Barry, K.C.V.O., and the officers of the ship The Pavilion of the Club was crowded by all the well-known people of Port Said, all the Consular Services being present. A cricket match was played between Officers of the ship and the P.S.C.C. resulting in a win for the Club. During the match, an excellent tea was served provided by Mrs. Tweedie and other ladies of Port Said. The Admiral kindly lent the ship's band, whose playing was most enjoyable and much enchan- ced the afternoon's enjoyment.

A dinner was given on board by the Ad- miral, at which several of the Port Said residents were present. A tennis match was also played by the officers against Port Said Tennis Club, resulting in a win for Port Said. The following was the result:- Dr. Hayward and Mr. Ingram beat Com- manders Harper and Trewby 6 to 4—6 to 3. Mr. Broatch and Mr. Howe beat Commanders Harper and Trewby 6 to 1—6 to 3. Dr. Hayward and Mr. Ingram beat Mr. King and Mr. H. W. Jackson, 6 to 2—6 to 1. Mr. Broatch and Mr. Howe beat Com- manders Harper and Trewby, 6 to 0—6 to 3.

On Monday afternoon, the Admiral and Officers gave a very enjoyable "At Home" on ship, which was open for inspection and the band played an excellent selection of music. In the evening a smoking concert was given by the men at Navy House. On Tuesday another cricket match, played on the club ground, between officers and members of the P.S.C.C.U. lower deck, resulted in win for the lower deck, the men's bowling being very good. On Wednesday, the officers and lower deck and P.S.C.C. played the P. & 0. S.S. "Moldavia", twelve a side, the victory being with the Club. In the evening, the officers entertained at dinner some of the players, and after dinner billiard and bridge matches were arranged. Port Said won at billiards, but was defeated at bridge. After a most enjoyable stay at Port Said, the ship left this morning at 6 a.m. to join the fleet.
P.S.C.C. v. H.M.S. "BACCHANTE."

div.head: BRITISH COTTON-GROWING ASSOCIATION.
div.p: The Duke of Marlborough on Wednesday week entertained Sir Alfred Jones and the Council of the British Cotton Growing Asso- ciation to a banquet in the Constitutional Club. Mr. Winston Churchill, M.P., proposing pros- perity to the Association, said one weak spot in the magnificent cotton industry of this country was the danger of a corner in the raw material by improper speculation in American markets. Our safeguard lay in broadening and multiplying the areas of cotton supply, and Nigerian railways and other developments which would effect the security of the supply, would have every scrap of his influence. Sir Alfred Jones said Africa would soon send £1,000,000 sterling per annum to this country.

div.head: LIBERTY OF THE PRESS IN EGYPT.
div.p: The following letter appears in the "Stan- dard":

Sir,-I have received a letter from a young Arab who is well known to me, and who is now working under the Government in Egypt. The following quoatation may be of interest, especially as I can vouch for the honesty of purpose, the fidelity to England and English interest, and intelligency of the writer :-

"Do you hear about Egypt and the Arabic papers? Many of them speak rudely against the English and the Army of Occupation. The one thing that has spoiled Egypt is the freedom of the Press; they should not have been allow- ed so much of it. I notice from the Egyp- tians here that they dislike the English, but when they stand in the presence of an English- man they curl their tails like dogs, and use the word 'sir' very frequently. But when they gather together in a public place, every one speaks out, and displays his impudence."
I am, Sir, your obedient servant. ONE WHO HAS LIVED AMONG ARABS FOR MANY YEARS

div.head: MOSQUES AND CHRISTIANS.
div.p: Constantinople has at present a little episode which may be said to present some analogy to the recent "Mikado" question in England. The Golden Horn also suffers under an unexpected interdict, and one that causes both irritation and dissapointment to thousands of tourists. Hitherto Christians have been as free to roam the mosques as Moslems, whereas now the former are forbidden to enter. The reason for the interdict is almost as singular as that against "The Mikado" in England. There are susceptibilities in the case. Some time since the Sultan sent to the Yemen a mission to try to achieve by persuasion the pacification that arms have failed to secure. The mission has recently returned to Stamboul accompanied by a number of Sheikhs of the Yemen, all perfervid Moslems who pray in the mosques daily and who have never seen a Christian in their lives. To meet one, and especially a woman, in the very sanctuary of Islam, would destroy their allegiance to the Commander of the Faithful. And as everything is to be done to conciliate their fanaticism, no Christians must be seen in the mosques

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
VOYAGES D'ETE A PRIX REDUITS.
div.p: La Khedivial Mail Line mettra en vente a ses Agences d'Alexandrie, du Caire et de Port Said des billets speciaux d'aller et retour qui permettront aux personnes desireuses de se rafrachir par un petit voyage en Grece, a SMYRNE, METELIN, CONSTANTINOPLE ou en SYRIE, de le faire a un taux reduit pendant les mois de JUILLET et AOUT.
La nourriture pendant deux jours de qua- rantaine est comprise dans ces prix.

Des prix reduits seront accordes aux passa- gers par plusiers hotels a Costantinople, comme aussi an Phalere, Athenes, etc., et si les passagers en premiere classe desirent rester a bord a Constantinople et retourner par le meme vapeur, ils auront la faculte de le faire en payant Fcs. 10 par jour pour leur nour- riture.

Pour la Sylie on emettrs. egalement des billets speciaux su prix du voyage simple pour le voyage de l'aller et de retour. Le prix du voyage d'Alexandrie a Beyrouth et retour sera done L.E. 3,500 par personne en premiere classe et L.E. 2,600 en deuxieme classe.
CONDITIONS.
Les billets pour ces voyages ne pourront etre obtenus qu'aux Agences de la Compagnie a Alexandrie, Port-Said et au Caire (Bonded Stores).
Les billets seront strictement personnels et aucune autre reduction ne sera accordee.

La duree de la validite des billets est de trois semaines a compter de l'arrivee au port de destination. Leur validite ne peut pas etre prolongee sauf contre paiement de la difference entre le prix de ces billets et celui des billets ordinaires.
Les passagers munis de ces billets n'auront pas la faculte de s'arreter dans les ports inter- inediaires.
Alexandrie, le 14 juin 1907. 30586-14-4
